title: 107_s1273
content: The "Improving Health Care in Rural America Act" establishes grant programs for rural health services outreach, rural health network development, and small health care provider quality improvement. The purpose of this section is to provide grants for expanded delivery of health services in rural areas, integrated health care networks, and small health care provider quality improvement activities. Definitions include terms like 'Director', 'Federally qualified health center', 'rural health clinic', and 'health professional shortage area'. The Secretary will establish a small health care provider quality improvement grant program under section 301. The rural health services outreach, rural health network development, and small health care provider quality improvement grant programs will be administered by the Director of the Office of Rural Health Policy. The Health Resources and Services Administration, in consultation with State offices of rural health, may award grants to expand access to essential health services in rural areas. Grants can be used to promote expanded delivery of health services and enhance the quality of care. The Director may award grants to eligible entities for rural health services outreach to expand delivery of health services in rural areas for up to 3 years. Eligible entities can receive grants to promote integrated health care networks and small health care provider quality improvement activities. To be eligible for a grant under this subsection, an entity must be a rural public or nonprofit private entity representing a consortium of 3 or more health care providers. The entity should not have previously received a grant for the project and must submit an application in consultation with the State office of rural health. The applicant must submit an application to the Secretary with details about the project, how it will address the health care needs of rural underserved populations, community involvement, sustainability plan post-Federal support. The Director may award rural health network development grants to eligible entities to promote the development of integrated health care networks in rural areas, aiming to achieve efficiencies, expand access to essential health services, and strengthen the rural health care system. The Director may award rural health network development grants to eligible entities for implementation activities lasting 3 years or planning activities lasting 1 year. Eligible entities must be rural public or nonprofit private entities representing a network of members. To be eligible for a rural health network development grant, entities must represent a network of 3 or more healthcare providers, be nonprofit or for-profit, and not have received a grant previously. Applications must be submitted to the Secretary with required information, in consultation with the State office of rural health. The applicant for a rural health network development grant must provide detailed information including a project description, reasons for needing federal assistance, history of collaborative activities, readiness for integration, and community benefits. The Director may award grants for small health care provider quality improvement activities for 1 to 3 years, focusing on planning and implementation. The applicant for a rural health network development grant must provide a project description, reasons for federal assistance, collaborative history, integration readiness, community benefits, increased access to quality health services, sustainability plan, and project evaluation description. To be eligible for a grant under this subsection, an entity must be a rural public or nonprofit private health care provider, another rural provider or network of small rural providers identified by the Secretary, or have not previously received a grant for the project. Eligible entities must prepare and submit applications in consultation with the appropriate State office of rural health or another State entity. The eligible entity must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant, detailing the project, the need for federal assistance, continuous quality improvement, and increased access to health services for the community. The eligible entity must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant, detailing the project, need for federal assistance, quality health services, sustainability plan, project evaluation, preference for entities in health shortage areas or serving underserved populations, and coordination with other agencies. The section authorizes appropriations for coordinating grant programs with federal, state agencies, and nonprofits to maximize funding impact for meritorious proposals. SEC. 3. CONSOLIDATION AND REAUTHORIZATION OF PROVISIONS. A new TELEHOMECARE DEMONSTRATION PROJECT is added to the Public Health Service Act. The Telehomecare Demonstration Project, defined as the provision of health services through technology to support home health services for rural residents, may be established by the Secretary within 9 months of the Health Care Safety Net Amendments of 2001. Grants may be provided for this demonstration project. The Secretary will make up to 5 grants to certified home care providers for telehomecare services in rural areas, lasting up to 3 years. Providers must submit applications and use funds to improve patient care and outcomes. The section outlines objectives to improve access to care for home care patients through direct telecommunications links, develop care management practices for nurses, and train healthcare professionals in the use of telecommunications. It also clarifies that the section does not modify coverage provisions. The section discusses the demonstration project's interim and final reports on the impact of telehomecare on access to care for home care patients. The section authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to improve access to care and quality of home care for patients.
